reviewText: While I cannot claim the "many of them" that "operamarty" can, I have seen perhaps a dozen, and have heard I don't know how many since I began listening to the Saturday broadcasts in the 1950s.  And I will rank this presentation as the best of them.  (Sadly, I did not see the Isola Jones performances of the 1980s.)Finally, we have a Carmen who can believably entice a loyal soldier into leaving his army, his girl back home, and, yes, even his mother, to go with her.  Elina Garanca exudes sensuality as she portrays this character.  There is a big difference between sensual and sexy, and Garanca makes the most of it.  The replacement of the usual dance, with her bathing her legs during the "Habanera," is a prime example.The Met's rotating stage was used to full advantage, as sets were reversed into new locations.  However, the closing scene, as the set turned to reveal Escamillo standing over the defeated bull, destroyed the feeling of the moment, and was, as "TheaterMania" called it, "crude and unnecessary."One of the major strengths of this presentation is the use of camera close-ups.  Look again at Carmen's expression as she is stabbed in the final scene.  One wonders how Garance could possible make the curtain calls after this.While this is the best Carmen I have seen, it is not without its flaws.  While the rest of the cast adequately fill their roles, they do not measure up to Garanca.  Roberto Alagna, as Don Jose, is beginning to show his age vocally, although he still exhibits the boyish exuberance of a young soldier, uncontrollably smitten.  Teddy Tahu Rhodes begins his portrayal of Escamillo as if he had learned only three hours before the performance that he was to sing that day--oh, yes, he did learn only three hours before.  However, as the play progresses, he does warm up to his part.  Barbara Frittoli's Micaela is the weak link of the principals.  She comes across as almost mechanical, lacking in feeling and character.  Perhaps she was frightened by the brutality of the soldiers in the opening act, which replaced the good-natured flirting usually seen.  Little has been written about him, but Keith Miller as Zuniga is the strongest of the supporting cast.The updating to the 1930s does nothing to add to the production, except a change in the soldiers' uniforms.  In fact, it is confusing as to the role of the smugglers.  So much so that one critic granted them "a degree of respectability" in the Franco generation, and another called them "a threat to the regular folks."  The use of Zippo lighters is questionable, being that they were not invented until 1936.  And I do not understood why the cigarette girls had to come from an underground "sweat shop" for their cigarette break, but came rushing from backstage after the fight inside.  Multiple entrances?  Or just inconsistentcy?However, even with these reservations, this the the best Carmen I have seen, and is a valuable addition to my collection.
summary: The best Carmen I have seen

reviewText: I saw this production when PBS showed it as part of the "Great Performances at the Met" series.  I had seen New York Magazine's review of the production headlined, "After 24 Years, the Met Finally Has a Great 'Carmen' Again," but was skeptical.  Over the years, I have heard about many productions that would finally be great, but always felt like something was lacking.  This production simply did leave all the others behind.One of the shortfalls of many Carmens is the performance of Carmen herself.  It is a challenging role that requires so much of a soprano, and few are able to meet the vocal and physical requirements.  In order for the role to work, the audience must believe that Carmen is so unbelievably desireable that she can cause men--any man she chooses--to throw away everything in life just to have a chance to be with her.  Ms. Garanca is one of a very few sopranos ever who can convey that degree of desireability.While the roles of Don Jose and Escamillo are not performed as ably as Ms. Garnaca's Carmen, that does not detract from the production.  For one thing, her setting of the bar is unbelievably high.  The two male leads do well with their roles--though Don Jose is better performed on this night.  Neither of them do anything that should spoil the performance for the casual opera fan.The orchestra, lighting, sets, and costumes are up to the normal Met standards--that is to say, very strong.If, like me, you have seen several productions of this opera without really loving it, give this one a try.  It may not turn "Carmen" into one of your favorite operas, but it will change the way you think of the opera forever.

reviewText: Elina Garana is a great Carmen. Passionate but subtle, with a great instrument that she knows how to invest with meaning. Alagna would have been a better Don Jose a few years ago. The role taxes his present voice to the limit and the high notes are not always on the mark. That he sings the climatic high note in his aria piano (as it should be by the way), though in falsetto, seems in his case a good idea for more than one reason. But his is nevertheless a very idiomatic and mostly very well sung Don Jose, with the right dramatic sense. Frittoli, without being a memorable Micaela, is good enough for the role and the last minute replacement for Escamillo saves the occasion without disgracing himself. The new production by Richard Eyre is a mixed bag, combining fresh and even brilliant ideas (Don Jose putting back Carmen's ring after killing her is just one of them) with some silly touches (Don Jose in the final duet brandishing an enormous cross at Carmen, who stands back in horror as if a vampire), but what really almost ruins for me the performance is the ridiculous setting. An ugly circular wall in ruins has to do for the square in Seville, a tavern, the mountains and even the exterior of the grandiose Maestranza bull ring. For no good reason updated apparently to the forties, during general Franco's dictatorship (although a guardia civil appears reading El País, a newspaper born with democracy many years later), this is a very gloomy Carmen. With no sign of sunny Spain, Carmen first appears to sing her Habanera saddened by the most unsexy outfit they could think of (one wonders why so many men are fussing about her!) and from a hole in the floor of the stage (go figure). Thank God at least for the final act they allow Carmen to show her sex-appeal with a beautifully designed black dress and mantilla. But for most part this looks like a performance of Carmen improvised in a concentration camp. Ugly and utterly against Bizet's ideas. His of course was also a fake Spain of just heat, sex and violence, but at least was more attractive to watch. So I loved Garana's Carmen (and the conducting) and quite enjoyed the rest of the singers, but I found the whole production quite depressing.

reviewText: Prequel: I have been informed by one reader that the reviews of Carmen at The Met (Garanca) and Carmen at the Opera Comique (Gardiner-Antonacci) have been muddled and posted wrongly. This is an error by Amazon and cannot be rectified by reviewers.My solution is to post both reviews under the one heading - Gardiner-Antonacci first followed by Garanca at the Met. If you are reading this review in the wrong place please be patient - it is beyond my control but both are here! Thanks, Ian Giles...........................................................................1: Review of Carmen at the Opera Comique - Gardiner and AntonacciThis recording, made in 2009, is a very different proposition to the many alternative versions currently available and for many reasons as will follow. Essentially Gardiner has returned to one of the three available versions to get back as far as possible to Bizet's original intentions. As a result the performance, uniquely performed on instruments of Bizet's period, was put on in the theatre that Bizet wrote it for. That theatre adds its own special characteristics. In addition there is a great deal more dialogue in this version than the alternative new versions which also claim to have restored the dialogue and there is also a great deal more actual music. Admirers of Anna Antonacci will also have noticed that this is now her second performance on video disc and this performance differs from her previous version at Glyndebourne in many ways.Technically this is a well recorded production which illustrated the different tonal characteristics of the period instruments and which equally clearly enables all the words, sung and spoken, to be heard within a believable balance. The visual recording deals with the generally dark and effective setting very well with fine detail and good colour definition. The sound is presented in both DTS and stereo. The opera is spread over two DVDs and there is a 21 minute extra item during which John Gardiner, Jerome Deschamps and Agnes Terrier discuss this particular production with enthusiasm. What is not fully discussed is the additional musical content which is a little frustrating. Also frustrating is the noisy 'jingle' which starts the second disc before the menu comes up. It is also a shame that there is not a blu-ray version available at present. It would be very irritating if that were to appear later with all the cost implications for original purchasers such as myself. Blu-ray would also get round the problem of having to change discs and configure the second separately.The production itself is traditional in both costuming and essential staging and seems to be very faithful to Bizet's probable original intention within this theatre. The theatre, the same used for the first performances, is small and intimate. The Dress Circle audience is apparently just 10 metres away from the singers. This closeness to the action and the enveloping acoustic characteristics of the building are well caught by the recording visually and sonically. The staging makes clever use of the limited space to create a two tier level and additionally the audience is involved in the action as the chorus and individual singers dramatically interact with the space in front of them - in effect the audience area.The members of the cast are all excellent. The intimate nature and period instruments both allow Gardiner to create a performance with far more use made of quiet delivery than usual. This brings about a far more subtle performance from everyone from soloists to full chorus. The chorus is Gardiner's regular Monteverdi Choir and this enhances the performance considerably being superior to most opera choruses in every way. The opera revolves around Carmen of course and Antonacci delivers a far more subtle and relaxed performance than her Royal Opera more 'stagey' and large-scale concept.(Which I also like in its different way). Significantly there is less violent hatred between her and Don Jose in this version and this is as a result of the dialogue as well as the acting and musical delivery. Andrew Richards as Don Jose delivers an equally subtle performance and the final conclusion is completely effective. This is quite different to the driven characterisations of Kaufmann or Alagna (at the Met) or Marcus Haddock's Don Jose at Glyndebourne.Amazingly, Anne-Catherine Gillet as Micaela almost steals the show with her youthful and innocent appearance and her heart-felt singing and dialogue. She has the longest applause during the performance, the most cheers at the final curtain call and the most roses thrown from the balconies! No more need be said about her other than this is the best Micaela I have ever seen or heard by an appreciable distance. The appropriately named Nicholas Cavalier makes a good, multi-layered Escamillo as a characterisation and is not out-shone by his fine colleagues. All the remaining solo cast are equally convincing.This is a gripping and illuminating production and performance. It should be on blu-ray although the DVD is clearly HD. It is unwise to suggest any performance as the 'best' as all fine performances and productions, and Carmen is fortunate to have many, will appeal in their own particular ways to individual viewers' personal tastes. However, this is a very different option and it is safe to say that there is really no viable comparison to make to challenge it at present. I would be happy to have this as my only version and even happier to have it as an additional version. As such it joins, in my personal order of preference, Sophie van Otter at Glyndebourne, Antonacci at the Royal opera and Garanca at the Met.Any one of these is a strong choice and I would suggest that this version by Gardiner at the Opera Comique is certainly another front runner to join them. I would expect most purchasers to find this totally absorbing and suggest that the full 5 stars is completely well earned...........................................................2: Review of Carmen at the Met - Garanca and AlagnaNow that this 'live' Met production has appeared on disc, many would rate this as the strongest contender for overall best buy especially as it pairs two of the finest singers available today in the key roles of Carmen and Don Jose.Both Garana and Alagna naturally dominate this production, and as they comment in their brief interview between acts, they both feel that their earlier experience of working together on Carmen in London has enabled them to further develop their working relationship. The result is clear to see as there is an unusually high degree of dramatic tension created between them throughout this production.In this performance Garana shows Carmen to be effectively focussed on her abilities to generate straightforward sexual desire in men she fancies and, as such, portrays a readily identifiable character type which will be fairly familiar. When apparently spurned she simply wishes to turn her attention to alternative options. This Carmen does not display the same level of inherent vindictiveness to be found in van Otter's Carmen at Glyndebourne or the violent unpleasantness portrayed by Antonacci at Covent Garden for example. This remains a very strong and believable portrayal of Carmen in its own right however and one that Garana clearly revels in.Alagna is on top form here and gives a fine performance of a role that he has been closely identified with for years. As mentioned above, the previous on-stage partnership with Garana in Carmen has allowed a further deepening of the Carmen/Don Jose relationship which adds considerable veracity to this production.The remaining roles are also well done with Barbara Frittoli an especially believable Micaela and one that Don Jose might well have been happy with under better circumstances. She is a stronger and more attractive portrayal than many rivals in a difficult role to project. Teddy Rhodes delivers an effectively self-possessed Escamillo with a suitably strong voice and matching characterisation. The remaining supporting roles are all of the same uniformly high quality.The setting of this Carmen is noticeably less sumptuous than either the Glyndebourne or Royal Opera productions which are particularly strong in creating apparently historically accurate and detailed scenarios. This Met production, although effective in its own way, does not really match either of those rival performances. Given the excellence of all three productions as regards both singing and acting, this may be a key matter for consideration for some. Nevertheless, apart from that consideration, no-one should be disappointed with this Met production.In summary, both Alagna and Garana are both on top form and achieve real dramatic intensity together. They are given excellent support from the rest of the cast and the orchestra under the talented Nezet-Seguin. The camera work is involving and of good imaging quality and the sound is presented in clear DTS-HD plus stereo quality. The usual Met backstage interviews and comment form the bonus material.As mentioned in the title to this review, there are now three fine modern but contrasting Carmens for purchasers to choose from, the others being from Glyndebourne and the Royal Opera at Covent Garden. My reviews for those are posted under their respective discs. All three are capable of generating enthusiastic support seen from their differing perspectives and will satisfy a considerable range of personal tastes and responses.I would therefore suggest that all three of these recent issues are worth the full 5 stars. Final choice will therefore correctly be largely a matter of personal preference at this stage, a decision which must lie outside the scope of this review.I would also suggest considering the fine period performance with Antonacci and conducted by Gardiner at the Opera Comique............................................Some dialogue from the comments section that may offer further help:Thank you! reviewText: I've seen many Carmans, including "on ice," & they're all good. Read enough synopsises & you won't even need to read the subtitles; just sit back & enjoy the music. A french opera set in Spain. It's hard call either of the two main casts a protagonist, because they spend the entire opera antagonizing eachother among others. It's a rare girl-power opera too; all the women in this opera save one are self-sufficient, driven, & carefree. Honestly, i'm going off the live Seattle Opera I just saw yesterday, but I don;t imagine their's much of a difference.Meet Carmencita: A sociopath, a free spirit, a gypsy, a hippie of her times, a proud boastful hedonist, a woman who dates on flight of fancy but truly has no love in her heart, as love is what she calls lust; love is something to her fleeting & nonlasting. She will play a game of cat-&-mouse with Don Jose.Meet Don Jose: A stubborn naive fool who is ruled by his hormones & lives for the hunt. A man who doesn't do his research before involving himself. A man who takes great risks without making plans.Don Jose finds himself to be a corporal, requested to return home to his mother with forgiveness (though why is never stated) & to marry, with a big hint-hint from the neighbor/messenger girl Micaela who seems more than willing. But this is too easy for Don Jose; why take a willing simple girl you've known since childhood when you can pursuit an exotic woman of poor reputation who is sending you mixed messages?Carmencita or Carmen for short, flirts with every guy in town, as do the other gypsies, because sex sells & they've got hand-made cigarettes to make money off of. Plus Carmen is an attention whore who eats her popularity like it was cake. On a whim, she tosses her flower to Don Jose, & he decides that she is hitting on him specifically, even though she laughs in his face afterwards. This just makes him want her more.Carmen latter gets into a knife fight with another gypsy & flirts with Don Jose so that he will be her willing dupe to get her escape jail. This works & he gets demoted & apparent;y a short prison sentence for insubordination.In the 2ed act, a popular egotistical charismatic bullfighter named Escamillo comes to the gypsy tavern to flirt with the ladies & tell everyone how awesome he is. He flirts with Carmen & she tells him to shove off, but tells only her friends & coworkers that she's "in love."Everybody leaves the tavern & in strolls a drunk Don Jose. Feeling a tad guilty for using him as a dupe earlier, Carmen offers him free food & wine & dances for him. He still has a thing for her, so to discourage him, she pretends to like him & pretends to be peeved when he has to leave for role call. She asks him to choose between his job & her, knowing he will choose the former else he be branded a deserter.Unfortunately his superior officer walks in & Carmen's coworkers choose this moment to spring a trap. They hang & shoot the superior officer, & immediately set to smuggling contraband out of town. Don Jose has no choice but to join them, as he would also be shot before the gypsies would let him run & report the killing. At the camp, Carmen & her best friends use tarot cards to predict their futures; Carmen's is death.So he is forced to live as a homeless vagabond at the gypsy camp, blaming all of this on Carmen & deciding that they are an official couple, even though she wants him to go away & leave her alone. He is finally dragged away by the woman who could have been his wife to see his dying mother.Time passes & Carmen is dating Escamillo; the attraction is mutual between them, they have much in common personality & popularity wise, also Escamillo has done his research on Carmen & knows the romance will likely be a short lived fling, & he's fine with that.Carmen's friends tells her Don Jose showed up in tattered rags looking for her, so she goes to confront him, completely expecting him to try & kill her. When he demands that she choose him or die, she gives him her "bring it" gesture, & he does.There is a little continuity error in this opera; it ends with Don Jose standing over Carmen's corpse in front of the arena, saying he will wait for the police to take him away, but the opera opens with Carmen's corpse being found by surprise on a street with Don Jose nowhere in site. This suggests that either the particular opera I saw needs an editor, or Don Jose had a change of heart, dragged Carmen's body off, & ran away.
summary: I recommend any version of this opera.

Difficult to imagine how hard it was for these two to go through the action and sing at the same time in this final scene.  I loved every minute of it and saw it several times.  I highly recommend this as one of the best opera DVD's available!  The entire cast was excellent!  Unlike the other reviewer, I liked the ballet and the bull.  One of the best touches was Don Jose putting the ring on dead Carmen's finger.  That was chilling!  If you haven't seen this Carmen, do yourself a favor and order the DVD.
